hints.content: What is binary?
Try finding a binary to plaintext converter.
Florets of flowers, scales of pinecones, patterns of seashells.
Named after a mathematician from the Republic of Pisa.
Those beeps have been used to communicate since the days of the telegraph.
Anyone up for S'MORSE.

What are these strange markings.answer: FLAG{IT JUST HAD TO BE QWERTY}

hints.content: Look at your keyboard keys.
Could the keys be a key to the cipher.
Use QWERTYUIOPASDFGHJKLZXCVBNM key order as the key for the substitution cipher.
You will need three different conversion tools.
??? -> Hex -> ASCII numbers -> ???
What is a book cipher?
Could the numbers represent locations in the book?
Each set of numbers represents: paragraph, line, word
If a password has not been changed from the default setting, what would it be?
Search for the default username/password combination of a Netgear MR314 router.
Resolve the DNS lookup for 'scoreboard.ctfmagic.org'
The encoding format used is Base64.
Find a tool to convert Base64 to text.
How can you search through all files in a directory with grep.
The given hash is in SHA1 format.
An online decryption tool will work fine.
The flag is encoded in octal.
Use an online TXT record lookup for 'magicinc.org'
Use either the 'find' or the 'locate' command.
Resolve the owner of the file.
The flag is encoded in hex format.
Pay attention to the name of this puzzle.
Find a way to show hidden files within Linux.
I feel like i've seen those lines before. Maybe with the way lifeguards communicate?
It seems odd that only specific letters are capitalized in the sentences underneath the lines.
It seems like the sentence underneath of the lines is code for some algorithm.
Use 'Audacity' to find your flag.
A black and white image can be rendered into sound. I'm sure there's a guide somewhere.
You can crack certain zip files using John the Ripper.
This puzzle builds off of crackit. The crunch tool can be used to generate wordlists using known characteristics.
The original .zip file has been split into parts using the 'split' command.
Use the 'cat' command to restore the file.
Extract the hidden files in the .img file.
Look at the header of the .png file in a hex editor.
Use your hex editor to modify the magic numbers of a png file.
Use an editor to view the contents of your file.
There is some junk data in the beginning of ending of your file. Check there.
Try to find a filter within Wireshark to search for strings.
Use 'frame contains' filter
Use the 'file' command to apropriately identify the file type.
How can you decompile a python script.
Try to use 'uncompyle2' lib.
The width and height of this image are not true to their real values. What defines these values?
Use Wireshark to intercept packets transmitted by the bot.
Make sure the program is executing the correct function.
This is the TowerOfHanoi game. How can you fix it?
Use openssl to decode the message in the given key.
The 'heart.encrypted' is the 'key.' You need to decrypt this.
You will need to modify your wordlist as the format is: 'flag{}'
You can modify built in wordlists using the 'awk' command.
Using 'scanem,' select the program's process and isolate the changing number.
Isolate the number by observing the changes of various values. There will be some trial and error.
Set the value of the remaining results to 5 using the 'set' command.
Use python 'unpack' and refer to the last 8 bytes sent from the server.
Add the two numbers in the tuple together then resubmit them to the server
Use a forensics tool to examine the '.venm' file.
Use the netscan plugin in volatility to view the connections in the '.venm'.
The volatility plugin 'procdump' can pull an executable from the '.venm'
Use a packet capturing program to intercept packets sent by the bot.
Use the 'frame contains' filter again like earlier.
